stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on a factory level for 'Return to Yoshi's Island', focusing on implementing visual effects like sparkles on wires, fixing bugs related to player states and camera behavior, and importing new assets from artist Biobak. The stream featured significant real-time collaboration with Biobak via chat to solve a technical issue in Blender.

development_findings.summary: Kaze programmed a sparkle effect to follow wires, but it was bugged. He used debug visuals and traced the issue to a mathematical error in his code, where he had forgotten a square root calculation.
development_findings.quote: I forgot the SQR, okay now it works. I'm not even gonna test if it works, I just know it works.

development_findings.summary: A persistent, unfixable rendering bug related to lighting effects exists in the level, which Kaze attributes to a flaw in the GlideN64 plugin.
Kaze is using Blender 4 but expressed frustration with changes to the software, particularly an issue where he could not easily select vertex colors, requiring help from Biobak.
development_findings.quote: Oh yeah, we're on the new Blender 4 and I am not a fan of it. They messed up some important things.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented a fixed camera for an elevator section, troubleshooting a clipping issue by moving both the camera position and the elevator's collision volume further inward.

Kaze is working from a detailed to-do list for the level, systematically implementing features and bug fixes, such as changing decal colors during the fuzzy effect and preventing Mario's safe position from updating while on a ledge.

The dizzy effect from touching a Fuzzy enemy was causing a visual bug on screen decals. The fix required getting the exact vertex color from the model in Blender and applying it as a prim color during the effect.

context_findings.summary: Kaze harbors a deep dislike for Super Mario Sunshine, primarily due to its frequent, unskippable cutscenes that interrupt gameplay and a progression system where many collectibles feel meaningless.
context_findings.quote: Every single time the game takes control away from me, it just feels like a small kick to my balls.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses significant frustration with German bureaucracy, which continues to be a source of stress despite him no longer living in the country.
context_findings.quote: I have accepted that most code is written pretty unoptimized. I just turn into a sad cat when I have to deal with German bureaucracy.

context_findings.summary: He is a fan of the TV show 'The Boys', acknowledging it as 'trashy' but appreciating how it 'hits my brain just right' and makes fun of politics.
context_findings.quote: There's so much like useless violence and like close-up of people's buttholes in the show like it is a trashy show, I think that's fair to say.

context_findings.summary: Kaze criticizes the level design of modern 3D Sonic games like Generations and Forces, where the camera and speed make it impossible to see upcoming obstacles, a problem he feels they introduced on purpose.
Kaze announced the themes for the final two main levels: Course 14 will be a 'Space Casino' and Course 15 will be a 'Paper Craft level'.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided real-time feedback in chat, pointing out that Kaze had imported an incorrect fan model, which prompted Kaze to find and implement the correct, higher-quality asset.
Biobak redesigned the factory level, creating new assets that Kaze imported. Kaze noted that Biobak's optimizations, such as removing textures, have improved game performance.
He assisted Kaze in troubleshooting a technical issue with Blender 4, guiding him on how to use the color picker for vertex colors to fix a visual bug.
Biobak provided text for a talkable janitor character, who will be included as an easter egg in the level.

badub.summary: Kaze specifically praised the music Badub created for the 'dizzy' effect when Mario touches a Fuzzy enemy, highlighting it as a cool and effective piece.

zeina.summary: Kaze noted he is waiting for Bowser's chair animations, which Zeina is responsible for and is expected to work on soon.
Zeina was present in the stream chat, and her departure was casually announced by Kaze, indicating a relaxed personal dynamic.
zeina.quote: See you, Zaina. Zaina has to go because her mom said, Nope, you're done.

key_stories.title: Fixing the Dizzy Vision
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed to fix a visual bug in the 'dizzy' effect. He couldn't figure out how to select the correct color in the new version of Blender until Biobak provided real-time technical support in the stream chat, enabling Kaze to code the fix.
key_stories.challenge: A visual effect for getting dizzy from an enemy had a graphical glitch: an ugly colored 'rim' appeared on the edge of the screen.
key_stories.process: Kaze identified the problem as needing to match the decal's prim color to the effect's vertex colors. He struggled with Blender 4's new interface to find the color value. Biobak, watching the stream, provided step-by-step instructions in the chat.
key_stories.outcome: With Biobak's guidance, Kaze found the color value and implemented a fix that changed the decal's color during the effect, successfully removing the rim. A subsequent issue with the color not resetting was solved by re-exporting the level.
key_stories.key_quote: Wayback, have you ever figured out how to pick a colour in this new blender version? I can't seem to do it.

key_stories.title: The Case of the Impostor Fan
key_stories.summary: Kaze implemented a fan model in the level that looked subpar. The asset's creator, Biobak, saw it on stream and immediately disowned it, leading Kaze to realize he'd used the wrong file and replace it with the correct, higher-quality model.
key_stories.challenge: While implementing assets for the factory level, Kaze noticed a spinning fan model didn't look right and its lighting seemed off.
key_stories.process: Kaze showed the spinning fan on stream. Biobak, the artist, immediately stated in the chat that the model shown was not his work. This prompted Kaze to check his files, where he discovered he had used an older, incorrect asset.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze located and imported the correct fan model made by Biobak. The new asset looked significantly better and integrated properly with the level's visual style.

key_stories.title: Debugging the Electric Sparkles
key_stories.summary: Kaze's initial attempt to code a sparkle effect resulted in a bug where all particles spawned in the wrong place. By using debug models and reviewing his code, he pinpointed and fixed a single mathematical error, making the effect work as intended.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needed to create a visual effect of electrical sparkles traveling along wires in the factory.
key_stories.process: Kaze wrote the code to spawn objects along a spline. To debug, he used Mario models as visual markers, which were all appearing in a single incorrect location. After ruling out pointer issues, he examined his math and realized he had forgotten to apply a square root (`SQR`) in the distance calculation.
key_stories.outcome: After discovering the missing square root function, the sparkles behaved correctly. Kaze then proceeded to fine-tune the effect's speed, size, and density for better visual appeal.
key_stories.key_quote: What the hell, why are all my Mario's over here?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions he is waiting on Bowser's chair animations from Zeina and plans to work on them 'tomorrow or so'.
questions: What is your process for creating animations for the N64?
What are the unique challenges or limitations of animating for this hardware?
How does the creative and technical handover between you and Kaze work for animations?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions the factory level is a complete redesign by Biobak of a level from a previous project ('OnlyBodyMay').
questions: What was the original 'OnlyBodyMay' level like, and what prompted the decision to completely remake it for this project?
What were your main goals with the redesign? What elements did you want to preserve versus what did you want to change?
Kaze mentioned you still have more assets to create for the level. What is your full vision for the space?

open_questions.context: Kaze played music by Badub and specifically praised the theme for the 'dizzy' effect.
questions: What was the creative brief for the 'dizzy' effect music? How do you translate a gameplay mechanic into a musical piece?
What is the general collaborative process like with Kaze? Does he provide gameplay footage, concept art, or just a description of the desired mood?
How do you balance creating new compositions while also leveraging the classic Mario 64 soundfont?

open_questions.context: Kaze announced that the final two levels will be a 'Space Casino' and a 'Paper Craft' world.
questions: Where did the ideas for a 'Space Casino' and 'Paper Craft' level come from?
What core gameplay mechanics or ideas are you most excited to explore with these unique themes?
Are there any specific games or media that are inspiring the design of these levels?

open_questions.context: A bug was reported that could soft-lock Mario on a ledge. Kaze could not replicate it but implemented a preventative code change anyway.
questions: Can you describe the original report of the ledge soft-lock bug?
How confident are you that the fix you implemented addresses the root cause, even without being able to replicate it?
How do you typically prioritize fixing rare or hard-to-reproduce bugs versus developing new content?
